content: hey guys
welcome back to blackmagic craft i don't know what these are but they're
kind of everywhere in the woods around where i
live if you go into the bush you're gonna
find a couple things you're gonna find some deer
there's a deer over there there's another one and you're gonna end up
finding these weird stick don't i don't
know what they're called i'm cautious to call them tepees i don't think that's
appropriate tp is a i believe a lakota word
that means dwelling and these are certainly not dwellings i really think
these are just things that kids make when they're playing but
the other day i was out in the woods here going for a walk with my daughter
and i stumbled upon these ones now there's a lot of them in the area some
of them that are quite large actually but these
two just really stood out to me because they
seemed exceptionally creepy that day it was really gloomy and the water that
you might be able to see behind us here a couple days ago had flooded this area
as well it's starting to dry out but that scene of these weird
stick constructions on a gloomy day sticking
out of what looked like a swamp was super inspiring i thought it looked
really cool and it really got my gears turning and reminded me
of the swamps in witcher 3 and i figured it would be a great setting for
dnd i mean i've run many d encounters in settings like this i
figured why not build one a little miniature version
inspired by real life put in a story in a swamp
there could be some kind of like shaman or mystic
forest dwelling person that uses it to like read the bones or
scry or whatever in there i don't think it's a place they would live i don't
think it's a dwelling but it's maybe something someone like that would
uh would use for some sort of ritual so yeah that's what i'm building today
wooden stick hut tent thing that i found in the woods
in miniature form
while i was in the woods i collected a fair bit of twigs for this project
from a variety of different trees i took some poplar branches that i thought
would be perfect in scale for mini birch or poplar tree
trunks but i put those aside for another project
they're still pretty green and i want them to dry out before using them for
this build i stuck to totally dead and dried out twigs this would both
suit the look of the project and ensure that they would be more
stable to use in a build normally i avoid bases for buildings
when possible but this one really needed it so i cut out a piece of
mdf i wanted something really resistant to warping for this so
i didn't screw around with chipboard mdf can be beveled with a knife but it
takes a pretty long time on a thicker piece like this so i ended up jumping
outside and using an orbital sander for like 30
seconds to get a much better result with a fraction of the effort much like
building one of these in real life i started with a stick that had a y
shape at the top using hot glue i started to assemble the
structure i wasn't worried about big hot glue globs on the base as those
would end up covered later but i was pretty careful to be
clean and sparing with the hot glue on the top joints i was also careful to
check each twig to make sure its bark was nice and secure now i really wanted
to preserve as much of the bark and mossy growth as possible as it looked
great but on some of the twigs the bark was ready to fall off
and that could mean disaster later so any ones that had loose bark were
stripped first by simply rolling them between my fingers
this process was quite tedious but
eventually i got through it now i didn't make the structure totally solid
the ones i've encountered in the woods never were anyway
and i think to get solid walls it would have made the build look
way too hefty and bulky and i think it really would have killed some of the
charm since i didn't think of this thing as a
dwelling but more of a place for like a shaman or
something to maybe perform rituals in i didn't really think it was necessary for
it to imply that it was rain or weatherproof
to build up the base and encase the bottom of the twigs i
turned to sculpt the mold i really really love this stuff it dries
really fast it dries hard and it really doesn't shrink much in the process
it was a bit tricky to apply inside and in between the twigs
but not impossible and if you're wondering why i didn't just put this
down first and build off of it well it's simply because it wouldn't
instantly set and lock the twigs in place
and would have made for a very awkward assembly process had i gone that route
i didn't have any really dark brown paint so i just
mixed some up i also mixed in some carpenter's glue to make it stronger
this is essentially the same step or idea as my usual mod podge and
black paint mixture but i wanted mud and carpenter's glue would be
perfectly fine as a stand-in for mod podge on a piece like this that could
resist the shrinking of the glue and not cause any warping
i really wanted to mimic the fall or spring
messy ground cover in the woods by my home where i found the real tents so to
simulate dried leaves and debris i used dried tea this is just the contents
of some unused awful tasting tea bags that i'd
never get around to drinking and to attach it i just sprayed on some
very very thinned matte mod podge you can buy this
pre-mixed in the spritz bottle like i have here or you could easily make your
own watered-down plain pva would probably
also be sufficient but i do find the extra additives in the
mod podge to be really helpful also i was able to make use of the bark
debris that i had stripped off the twigs earlier
to add some more variety of color shape and texture
i did think that the structure needed something a little more to give it some
character so i decided to veer off from the real inspiration
and give it a simple tarp door for this i used paper towel
soaked in that diluted mod podge i really would have preferred something
like a shop towel that had no texture but this was all i had so the little bit
of texture on it would make it look more like
burlap or fabric rather than say something like an animal hide
and normally i'd let this part dry before painting it
but i realized that painting the backside would be
very difficult and you'd be able to see it through the cracks
in the twigs so while everything was still wet i jumped over to the spray
booth and hit it with some sepia wash in the
hopes that it would soak up the color and go all the way
through this only half worked and i had to
awkwardly spray between the cracks a little bit to hit the entire backside
in the process i also sprayed the ground covering and the twigs with the sepia
wash and a bit of diluted black ink in
certain areas this helped to kind of bring everything
together to tie it all in color wise and it also made the greenish tea bag
fillings look a little bit more like dried fall leaves
while that dried i jumped back over to my
workbench and worked on another little detail to dress up the piece i figured a
bone reading shaman may indicate their place of work with some sort of sign and
what would be a more appropriate sign than a string of skulls
and bones the box of citadel skulls is perfect for this man i'm getting so much
mileage out of this purchase i cut out a few human skulls
a bird skull and a big piece of jawbone for the rope
i like using this metal jewelry wire because it stays nice and stiff
and it looks like rope at scale the hard part though would be getting a hole
in the tiny skulls to feed the wire through at first
i tried drilling with a pin vise but the particular plastic they use on these
skulls is really hard to drill through as it
sort of just melts and gums up the bit eventually i
had to go for a rotary tool which is super difficult and sketchy on
such a tiny piece after a lot of fiddling
super glue and baking soda mess i got a usable piece that i primed in
beige to get it a nice bone color i used some
gw contrast paint and in the process said well screw it right
why not just dip the whole thing in the pot
the piece was looking a little bit bland and monotone
so i added a few grass and bush tufts to give it just a bit of
contrast and because i love juxtaposition so much i did decide to
add some pretty little spring flowers around the creepy structure
i'm really happy with the way this project turned out it might not end up
getting a lot of in-game use but it was just so satisfying to make
it's not often in the genres that i build in that i get
to find a real world thing collect materials from the real
world and replicate it in miniature form this
was just super fun and it's gonna be a really memorable
piece for me so what do you guys think i think that
was a pretty cool little project i'm curious to know
are these things really common in the woods around where you live
if you have woods do you know anything about them is this really just bored
kids i mean it probably is i don't think it's
like a blair witch type situation but it's really neat let me know in the
comments if you've come across these sort of things
in your area if you enjoyed this video and i hope that you did hit the like
button and let me know in the comments section
below if you need to pick up any tools or supplies to build your own
check out blackmagicraft.ca there i have my essential equipment page with
a link to all of the stuff that i use and recommend and you can get the right
thing get it delivered to your house and also i will put
some links in the video description below to key elements used on
this project if you really enjoy these videos that i make each and every week
and you want to help me keep making them the best
way you can do that is by supporting the channel on patreon it's through those
funds that i'm able to allocate so many reasons
another deer running by so many resources to
making these videos every week and i couldn't do it without you guys so
thanks to all my current past and hopefully future
patrons i'd love to see you as the newest member of the black magic craft
fellowship that's it for this week guys i'm going
to keep wandering and see if maybe i can find something else cool
to inspire next week's project cheers
